conclusion: Analyze the motion of both the pedestrian and the bus using the given velocity-time (v-t) graphs.
The pedestrian's velocity is constant and is given by the y-intercept of the graph.
The pedestrian's velocity is \( v_p = 8 \) m/s.
The pedestrian starts 36 meters behind the bus and runs at a constant speed of 8 m/s.
The time taken for the pedestrian to cover the 36 meters is \( t = \frac{36 \text{ m}}{8 \text{ m/s}} = 4.5 \) s.
The bus starts from rest and accelerates uniformly. The graph shows that the bus's velocity increases linearly with time.
The slope of the bus's v-t graph gives the acceleration, which is \( \frac{8 \text{ m/s} - 0 \text{ m/s}}{8 \text{ s}} = 1 \) m/s².
The acceleration of the bus is \( a = 1 \) m/s².
The distance traveled by the bus in time \( t \) is given by the area under the v-t graph, which is \( \frac{1}{2} \times 8 \text{ s} \times 8 \text{ m/s} = 32 \text{ m} \).
The pedestrian has been running for 4.5 s.
The distance traveled by the pedestrian is \( d_p = 8 \text{ m/s} \times 4.5 \text{ s} = 36 \text{ m} \).
The bus has been accelerating for 4.5 s.
The distance traveled by the bus in 4.5 s is \( d_b = \frac{1}{2} \times 1 \text{ m/s}^2 \times (4.5 \text{ s})^2 = 10.125 \text{ m} \).
The bus starts from rest and accelerates until it catches up with the pedestrian.
The distance traveled by the bus when the pedestrian catches up is \( d_b = d_p + 36 \).
Substituting the expressions for \( d_p \) and \( d_b \), we get \( \frac{1}{2} t^2 = 8t + 36 \).
